coredata.dc:title: Lithium anode in carbonate-based electrolyte: High-performance by self-protected solid-electrolyte-interphase
coredata.dc:creator: Fang, Shan
Zhang, Yan
Liu, Xiang
coredata.dc:description: Lithium metal is considered as the ultimate negative electrode for future high-energy batteries because of its lowest electrode potential and very high theoretical capacity. However, its practical application is severely plagued by the hazardous lithium dendritic growth upon charge and low coulombic efficiency resulting from the inhomogeneous mass and charge transfers across the Li/electrolyte interface. Herein we report an economical and effective approach to step out of this dilemma, using self-protected Solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) in carbonate-based electrolyte with Vinylethylene carbonate (VEC) additive. VEC as a sacrificing material can prevent the Li salts and solvent decomposition, and further free radical reaction of VEC decomposition products in-situ form self-protected highly uniform and mechanical strength SEI layer on Li metal surface. The versatile effects of this unique SEI layer are demonstrated by the uniform lithium plating/stripping and very high Coulombic efficiency (up to 96% after 150 cycles at 1 mA cm−2 with 1 mAh cm−2). Lithium metal batteries, employing the self-protected Li metal negative electrode coupled with LiFePO4, exhibit excellent performance in both cycling stability and rate capability. Even the anode free cell Cu|NMC811, an impressive high initial coulombic efficiency of 92.5% and promising improvement of cycling performance are achieved.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Lithium metal anode
Electrolyte additives
Solid-electrolyte interphase
Vinylethylene carbonate

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Cycling performance of the electrolytes with different volume fraction of VEC by Li|Cu cell at (a) 0.5 mA cm−2, 1 mAh cm−2, (b) 1 mA cm−2, 1 mAh cm−2. (c) Voltage–capacity curves of Li plating/stripping in the different electrolyte. (d) Exchange current density of the electrode in different electrolyte. Cycling performance of symmetric Li|Li cells with normal electrolyte (e) and with VEC-15 based electrolyte (f) at current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 with capacity of 1 mAh cm−2; (g, h) EIS of Li|Li cells at frequency ranging from 105 to 10−2 Hz under amplitude of 5 mV.

In situ optical microscopy observation of Li deposition on Cu foil (a) in the normal electrolyte; (b) in the electrolyte with VEC-15. The current density is 1 mA cm−2, the capacity of Li deposition is 0.5 mAh cm−2. Scale bar is 200 µm. SEM images of the surface morphology of the Li deposition on Cu foil after the 1st, 10th, 50th cycle at 1 mA cm−2 in the normal electrolyte (c–f), VEC-15 (g–j). The amounts of Li deposition were all fixed at 1 mAh cm−2.

XPS spectra of Cu electrode after 10th deposition in normal electrolyte of (a) C1s, (b) F1s and (c) P2p branches. VEC-based electrolyte (d) C1s, (e) F1s and (f) P2p branches. The analyses were performed at 0.5 mA cm–2, 1mAh cm–2. (g) The atomic portion of Li1s, P2p, C1s, O1s, F1s elements of the cycled Cu foil after 10th deposition in different electrolyte.

Voltage profile of Li|Cu cell in different electrolyte and the gas evolution of the cell during OCV and cycling investigated by DEMS, and the schematic of Li plating in different electrolyte: (a, b) in normal electrolyte. (c, d) in VEC-based electrolyte.

The digital photo of the electrolyte after several weeks (a) VEC-15 electrolyte, (b) 15 vol% VEC in EC/DMC without LiPF6. NMR spectra of 1 M LiPF6 + EC/DMC electrolyte without VEC (black), fresh VEC (red) and aged VEC-15 (blue): (c, d) 19F NMR spectra, (e) 31P NMR spectra (f) 13C NMR spectra. (g, h) ATR-FTIR spectra for LiPF6 + EC/DMC electrolytes with and without 15% VEC at different storage conditions.

(a) Schematic presentation of the hydrolysis of LiPF6. (b) PF5-catalyzed ring-opening polymerization of VEC. (c) Potential energy (underlined data) and Gibbs free energy profile (in kcal/mol) at 298.15 K for the reductive dissociation process of Li+(VEC) calculated with B3LYP/6-311G(d, p) methods. H: grey sphere, F: yellow sphere, O: red sphere, P: purple sphere; Li: blue sphere.

Electrochemical performance of Li||LFP full cells with different electrolyte: charge-discharge curves of selected cycles in (a) VEC electrolyte, and (b) normal electrolyte. (b) Cycling performance (d) rate performance. The SEM images of Li anode after 100 cycles (e) Li anode in normal electrolyte. (f) Li anode in VEC-15 electrolyte.

The first three charge/discharge curves of anode free Cu|NMC811 cell at 0.1C in different electrolyte: (a) in normal electrolyte. (b) in VEC-15 electrolyte. (c, d) The cycling performance of Cu|NMC811 cell in different electrolyte (1C = 200 mA g−1), and corresponding coulombic efficiency. The SEM images of Cu foil until cell failure: (e) Cu foil obtained from normal electrolyte. (f) Cu foil obtained from VEC-15 electrolyte.

head.ce:title: Lithium anode in carbonate-based electrolyte: High-performance by self-protected solid-electrolyte-interphase

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nanchang University, Nanchang, Jiangxi 330031, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Materials Science and Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Materials Science and Engineering, Nanchang University, Nanchang, Jiangxi 330031, China

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Engineering Research Center of Nuclear Technology Application, Ministry of Education, East China University of Technology, Nanchang 330013, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Engineering Research Center of Nuclear Technology Application

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Engineering Research Center of Nuclear Technology Application, Ministry of Education, East China University of Technology, Nanchang 330013, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Lithium metal is considered as the ultimate negative electrode for future high-energy batteries because of its lowest electrode potential and very high theoretical capacity. However, its practical application is severely plagued by the hazardous lithium dendritic growth upon charge and low coulombic efficiency resulting from the inhomogeneous mass and charge transfers across the Li/electrolyte interface. Herein we report an economical and effective approach to step out of this dilemma, using self-protected Solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) in carbonate-based electrolyte with Vinylethylene carbonate (VEC) additive. VEC as a sacrificing material can prevent the Li salts and solvent decomposition, and further free radical reaction of VEC decomposition products in-situ form self-protected highly uniform and mechanical strength SEI layer on Li metal surface. The versatile effects of this unique SEI layer are demonstrated by the uniform lithium plating/stripping and very high Coulombic efficiency (up to 96% after 150 cycles at 1 mA cm−2 with 1 mAh cm−2). Lithium metal batteries, employing the self-protected Li metal negative electrode coupled with LiFePO4, exhibit excellent performance in both cycling stability and rate capability. Even the anode free cell Cu|NMC811, an impressive high initial coulombic efficiency of 92.5% and promising improvement of cycling performance are achieved.

ce:section.ce:para: Li metal has been considered as a very promising anodes for high-energy density Li metal batteries, which possess high specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and low potential (−3.04 V versus the standard hydrogen potential) [1–4]. Unfortunately, the intrinsic nature of Li metal reacts easily with electrolyte, forming an inhomogeneous and mechanically fragile Solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer [5–9]. Due to the uncontrolled dendritic growth of Li and infinite volume changes, the SEI layer will be continuously broken and regenerated upon cycling, leading to endlessly consumption of both Li metal and electrolyte, significantly decreasing the Li plating/stripping coulombic efficiency, especially in normal carbonate electrolytes (1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC). Additionally, the Li metal surface will be covered by a thicken SEI layer and dead Li composite, which blocks Li-ion transport and leads to an exponential increase of resistance and cell failure, these intractable issues are the major challenges toward practical application lithium-metal batteries [10–13].

To increase the coulombic efficiency and suppress the Li dendrite as well as dead Li formation, numerous strategies have been conducted to combat these issues, including development of separators with functional polar groups [14–16], the use of three dimensional Li metal electrode [17–20] or current collectors [21–24], and surface engineering of lithium metal foil [25–29]. Adjusting the electrolyte composition, including Li salts [30], aprotic solvents [31], and additives [32–35], to modify SEI is considered to be a most viable, economical, and effective approach to enhance the electrochemical performance of Li anode. Particularly, highly concentrated lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) or lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) in glyme-based electrolytes [36–39], can avoid lithium dendrite growth and show good thermal stability. For example, 4 M LiFSI in DME enabled dendrite-free and high CE of Li metal batteries, but the low oxide potential of the electrolyte can only pair with low voltage cathode materials, such as LiFePO4 [30]. Thus, researcher developed dual salt high concentrate DME electrolyte (2 M LiTFSI + 2MLiDFOB in DME) achieving a very stable cycling performance of Li|NMC111 full cell [37]. Recently, even higher concentrated 6.9 M dual salt-DME electrolyte (4.6 M LiFSI + 2.3 M LiTFSI in DME) are reported, which can improve the cycling performance of Cu|NMC622 cell [39]. However, their practical uses in commercial batteries are severely hindered because the high viscosities, leading to low ionic conductivity and ion mobility, difficult to wetting the separator and electrode mismatch with the currently battery manufacture as well as the increased costs. Carbonate-based electrolytes with higher ionic conductivity, better wetting ability, wide electrochemical stability windows and lower flammability have been used exclusively in almost all the commercial lithium-ion batteries. Nevertheless, they are highly corrosive to metallic Li, rendering exacerbate dendrite formation and shorten cycle life. Selecting certain additives that alternate the composition and structure of SEI may resolve the instability problem of metallic Li in carbonate electrolyte, improving the limited lifetime of the lithium metal batteries.

Herein, we report that the coulombic efficiency and stability of Li anode can be significantly improved by self-protected highly uniform and mechanical strength SEI layer which is in situ formed by simply add a certain amount of solvent. VEC is a kind of electrolyte additives which can effectively protect graphite anode but the effects on the Li anode has rarely been reported [40,41]. The optimal VEC as an additive can significantly alter the interfacial reactions of Li anode in carbonate electrolyte. VEC with a higher HOMO and lower LUMO [42], more easy to reduce during cycling [43]. In addition, the double bond has high activity, which can be employed for polymerization reaction to form polymer network. Therefore, VEC as a sacrificing material can prohibit the Li salts and solvent (EC/DMC) decomposition, and further free radical reaction of VEC decomposition products form a self-protected, mechanical strength and compact SEI film. Compared to the normal carbonate electrolyte, the electrochemical performance of Li anode in the VEC added electrolyte shows significant improving, demonstrating long-term cycling approaching 1000 h in Li|Li symmetric cell with constant and smooth polarization curves, and high coulombic efficiency of the Li|Cu cells. Excellent performance in both cycling stability and rate capability were also demonstrated in the lithium metal full cells and anode-free cells.

The Li plating/stripping behavior of Li metal anode was investigated first by using a galvanostatic electrodeposition method in 1 M LiPF6 EC/DMC electrolyte (normal electrolyte) with the different volume fraction of VEC additives. The lithium plating areal capacity was fixed to 1.0 mAh cm−2 for all the tested cells and the results shown in Fig. 1 . At a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2, the cell using VEC additives electrolyte exhibit high initial coulombic efficiency, i.e. 95.3%, 96.3%, 95.2% and 94.3% for VEC − 5, VEC − 10, VEC − 15, and VEC − 20, respectively (Fig. 1a), compared with only 88.7% for the normal cell. Furthermore, the normal cell assembled shows prominent and irregular fluctuations during Li plating/striping with low coulombic efficiency, rapid failure after about 90 cycles. In contrast, a significant improved can be observed in the VEC additives electrolyte, especially the VEC − 15, the coulombic efficiency is still remained above 94.3% after 150 cycles, indicating high reversibility of Li plating/stripping. When increasing the current density to 1 mA cm−2, VEC − 15 still shows consistently stable and high coulombic efficiency of 95.5% after 100 cycles, while the normal cell degrades rapidly after only 60 cycles. These results imply that the VEC additives enable to improve the stability of the SEI layer, minimizing the direct contact of Li metal with electrolyte and promoting reversible Li plating/stripping. The coulombic efficiency dose not improved too much when the VEC volume fraction increased to 20%, which might ascribe to the high volume fractions of VEC increase the viscosity of the electrolyte, lowering the conductivities of the electrolyte (Fig. S1). The effect of stable SEI formation can also be certified by the reduced cell polarization during the Li plating/stripping. The nucleation and plateau over potential are employed to evaluate the procedures of Li nucleation and growth. Obviously, the nucleation voltage of Li in VEC-15 based electrolyte is much lower (~40 mV) than that of in the normal electrolyte (~360 mV) at 1 mA cm−2 (Fig. 1c, Fig. S2). The large polarization of normal cell is due to a highly resistive SEI layer increases the ion and electron diffusion resistance, generating high nucleation barrier for Li deposition and follow-up Li dendrite growth. While the VEC electrolyte exhibits a lower hysteresis is attributed to lower internal and charge transfer resistance resulting from the stable SEI layer [44]. The Li|Cu cell cycled at higher current density of 2 mA cm−2 with 2 mAh cm−2 are shown in Fig. S3. The coulombic efficiency in the normal electrolyte decreases dramatically as cycling progresses, the cell failed after 40 cycles. In comparison, the cell demonstrates much improved cycling performance in VEC-15 electrolyte, maintaining a coulombic efficiency of more than 90% over 80 cycles. Impressively, even the current density and deposition capacity was increased, the cell still show improved and stabilized performance in VEC-15 compared with that in normal electrolyte. The detailed voltage versus capacity profile in these two electrolyte were also compared. The overpotential for the initial electrochemical plating and stripping of lithium was much higher in the normal electrolyte than in the VEC-15 (Fig. S3b and c), indicating large barrier nucleation for lithium ions. The improved cycling performance at high current density and areal capacity is ascribed to the generation of a stable SEI and high reversible plating/stripping of Li in VEC-15 electrolyte.The exchange current density J0 values, calculated from the corresponding Tafel plots (Fig. 1d), can reflect the interfacial properties between the electrode and electrolyte components. The exchange current density for Li plating/stripping from electrolyte to the electrode surface in the VEC-15 is 0.65 mA cm−2, which is about three times higher than what is achieved in the normal electrolyte (J0 = 0.27 mA cm−2), indicating a fast mass transfer kinetics. In a low over potential region, the current density is governed by charge transfer between electrode and redox species, confirming the low surface diffusion barrier imparted by the VEC additive contribute in the SEI layer [45].

To further investigate the effective the of VEC electrolyte additive, the voltage hysteresis of Li plating/stripping and the cycling stability with and without electrolyte additive has been examined in symmetric Li|Li cells under a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 and fixed with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 1e and 1f). The plating/stripping voltage of the electrode with normal electrolyte increases with cycling depth. In the early cycles, around the 50 cycles (200 h), over-potential of approximately 60 mV was observed. This over-potential increased to 170–180 mV after 100 cycles and short-circuits after 500 h (Fig. S4), which can be ascribed to the continuous consumption of electrolyte and the accumulation of thick SEI, increase the migration resistance of Li ions at the electrode interface. In contrast, the cell assembled with VEC-15 electrolyte displayed much-improved cycling performance, offers a consistent, stable and low voltage hysteresis around 50 mV during the whole cycling lifetime and no voltage fluctuation were observed even after 1000 h. These results indicate the reversibility of utilizing the Li metal below the stable SEI layer. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was further tested for the symmetric cells. (Fig. 1g and 1 h) show the evolution of Nyquist plot for symmetric cells with different electrolyte resting for the first 96 h, providing the evidence of chemical stability of the SEI layer. From 0 − 96 h, the VEC-15 cell shows a lower and much more stable resistance, while the cell with the normal electrolyte increase dramatically. This clearly demonstrates the formation of a stable SEI layer with VEC additives, which, in turn, prevents the direct contact and parasitic reactions of the electrolyte with Li. In contrast, the resistance of normal cell increased, which indicates the continuous side reaction between the bare lithium and electrolyte on the account of the unstable SEI formation.

The lithium deposition process was monitored under optical microscopy using homemade transparent Li|Cu cell. In normal electrolyte, the uneven surface appeared after applying a current density of 1 mA cm−2 for 360 s (Fig. 2 a, Video S1). This surface became huge “mossy” clusters after the 1800 s as the deposition capacity increased. A completely different phenomenon was observed in the electrolyte with VEC-15 (Fig. 2b, Video S2). At the very beginning of the deposition with the same current density, the dim surface of the substrate should be the SEI formation including oligomers and more dense Li deposition which covered the Cu foil uniformly, decreasing the reflectively to light, during the whole process, no cluster formation was observed even after 1800 s, demonstrating Li was homogeneously deposited on the substrate. To obtain more insightful information, Li metal morphology evolution after different plating/stripping cycles in a Li|Cu cell was studied by SEM. In normal electrolyte, lithium dendrites with a typical diameter of several hundred nanometers were observed after 1st deposition at 1 mA cm−2 (Fig. 2c). After 10th and 50th deposition, the Li dendrites proliferation with the similar needle-like morphologies (Fig. 2d, e). These needle-like Li dendrites increase the contact area with electrolytes, resulting in parasitic interfacial reactions which in turn to decrease the coulombic efficiency and even penetrate through the separator, causing cell short circuit and safety issues. While with the VEC-15 electrolyte, the two-dimensional planar morphology of Li instead of dendrites were observed after 1st, 10th and 50th deposition (Fig. 2g–j, low magnification SEM image shown in Fig. S5). Notably, the Li deposition is more compact and denser with VEC-15 electrolyte (Fig. S6). After 10th and 50th cycles, the thickness of the dead Li increased from 46 to 83 µm in the normal cell, while for the cell with VEC additive, the thickness is only 50 µm after 50 cycles (Fig. S7). This indicates that less dead Li formed during the plating/stripping process. These results substantiate that the Li deposition can be reshaped to a dendrites-free behavior in VEC-based electrolyte.

To disclose the underlying mechanism about the interface stabilization for VEC-based electrolytes, the chemical composition of the SEI layer generated after 1st and 10th Li deposition was first investigated by XPS as shown in Fig. S8 and Fig. 3 . For the Li cycled in normal electrolyte and VEC-15 electrolyte, both spectra showed peaks at almost identical positions, but the peak component ratio were different. In the C 1 s branches (Fig. 3a and 3d), peaks at 290.0, 288.5, 286.0, and 284.8 eV are assigned to the Li2CO3 [46], ROCO2Li [47], C–O, and C–C bonds, respectively [48]. The carbon- and oxygen-containing peaks are attributed to the decomposition of both VEC and EC/DMC. According to the C 1 s profile of the VEC-15 case (Fig. 3d and Fig. S6d), the C-C bond was more pronounced with respect to other peaks when compared with that of the normal counterpart (Fig. 3a and Fig. S8a), even though VEC also have carbonyl groups, the intensities of other oxygen-containing peaks were lowered substantially. This observation may because the decomposition of VEC form radical to further polymerization, which could improve the stability of SEI layer, and in turn weakens the decomposition of EC/DMC. In the F 1 s branches (Fig. 3b and 3e), the peaks appeared at 689.6 eV, 687.0 eV and 684.6 eV corresponding to LixPFyOz, LixPFy and LiF bond, respectively [49]. All of these come from the decomposition of LiPF6. Comparing the P2p branch, it is strange that no signal after first deposition in normal electrolyte, we believe that this may due to the low content of P element. It can be observed that both F1s and P2p bare spectrum show a high noise, indicating the low content. However, after 10 cycles, addition to LixPFy, LixPFyOz compounds are also observed in VEC electrolytes, that might attributed to the exist of VEC helps LiPF6 and its decomposition products, such as POF3 proceed further reaction (POF3 + ne− + nLi+ → LiF↓ + LixPFyOz↓) to form LixPFyOz and LiF compound [50]. With regard to the atomic composition in the SEI layer, the atomic portion of C increased while that of O, P, and F decreased when VEC used as an additive (Fig. 3g). The XPS results demonstrate that the VEC additives suppresses the decomposition of EC/DMC and alters the composition of the SEI layer by its precedent participation in SEI formation. In VEC added electrolyte, the component ratio of Li2CO3 and LiF is relative high in the SEI layer, which may improve the ionic conductivity of SEI layers. Besides the inorganic compounds, more organic compounds are found in the SEI from the VEC-15 electrolytes. This is probably because VEC as a sacrificing material, decomposing through ring opening and radical polymerization consequently form oligomer products, which is good to form a mechanical strength SEI layer on the Li anode surface. Here, we have to mention that the polymerization reaction should not always present due to the limit amount of VEC, which in turn will not increase the internal resistance of the cell. This SEI layer is flexible and adheres well on the Li surface due to the polymer rich components, and it can suppress nonuniform growth of the Li layer and sustain higher surface tension during the Li deposition process. The corresponding elements in the SEI layers during cycling have been further confirmed with Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) measurements (Fig. S9 and S10). After 10 cycles, as compared to P (1.9%), F (10.6%), O (69.1%) and C (18.4%) measured in the SEI layer formed in normal electrolyte, lower contents of P (1.5%), F (5.6%), O (67.4%) and higher C (25.5%) elements are detected in the SEI formed in VEC-15 electrolyte, implying the polymer dominant SEI layer, which is ascribed to a significant participation of VEC into SEI formation, and the lower content of P and F suggesting the mitigated side reaction with the presence of VEC additive.

To further understand the suppressing decomposition effect of VEC additive in the electrolyte, gas evolution of Li|Cu cell with different electrolyte have been test during cycling by online continuous flow differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS). As shown in Fig. 4 , the cells were rest for 12 h at OCV, then plating and stripping at 0.5 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. The m/z = 28 corresponding to CO, which was already generated in the OCV period in both cell. Fig. 4a show the Li|Cu cell with normal electrolyte, H2 (m/z = 2), POF3 (m/z = 104), CO or C2H4 (m/z = 28, 27), CO2 (m/z = 44) and CH4 (m/z = 15) are generated during Li plating of the first cycle, and these signal disappeared in second cycle and found again in third and fourth cycle, resulting from the unstable SEI film formation and the newly deposited Li react with the electrolyte, causing the gas evolution. When the cell cycled with VEC additives, the gas evolution was greatly suppressed. Only H2 was observed during the first cycle, due to a more electrochemical stable and dense SEI layer formed on the surface of Li metal, serious gas evolution are suppressed. In the third cycle, in addition to the above-mentioned gas evolution, C4H6 and C2H5CHO were observed, which comes from the decomposition of VEC. Nonetheless, the gas evolution are much less than the cell with normal electrolyte, and all of these signals disappeared in the rest of cycles. These results demonstrate that the VEC additive dramatically reduces the gas evolution, because of the in-situ formed highly uniform and mechanical strength SEI layer on Li metal surface, prohibit the further reaction between Li anode and the electrolyte, suppressing electrolyte decomposition, and maintains stability of the anode during cycling, thus inhibiting later-cycle SEI formation and leading to greatly improved cycling stability.

During the experiments, we found that the electrolyte with VEC additives turned from transparent colorless to black after a few weeks, as shown in Fig. 5 a, even without charge/discharge. Moreover, when the electrolyte consists of 1 M LiPF6 with pure VEC, the colour changes in short time as shown in Fig. S11a (all the samples were storage in glovebox at room temperature). However, this phenomenon was not observed in pure VEC solvent (Fig. S11b), normal electrolyte, even the VEC-15 electrolyte without LiPF6 salt (only 15 vol% VEC in EC/DMC) (Fig. 5b). Cyclic voltammogram (CV) measurements were further carried out on Li|Cu cell at 0–2 V by using 1 M LiPF6 in pure VEC to certify the reaction of VEC when Li salt exist. As shown in Fig. S12, very small reductive current starts from 1.34 V and 0.7 V which disappeared at 2nd and 3rd cycle, we attribute these peaks to the decomposition of VEC. The reduction peak around 0.5 V is attributed to the under-potential deposition of Li [51], which is independent of VEC. This is further indicating LiPF6 salt will affect VEC stability, more discussion will provide in the following. The colour changed VEC-15 electrolyte was used to investigate the effect of the electrochemical performance. It is interesting that the cell still shows very high coulombic efficiency (Fig. S13) and low polarization voltage (Fig. S14), even better than the fresh VEC-based electrolyte. In order to identify the composition of aged electrolyte, different electrolyte without electrochemical test is characterized by NMR and ATR-FTIR. (Fig. 5c to 5e) and Fig. S15 to Fig. S16 are 19F and 31P NMR spectrum, both of this two element spectrum confirm the existence of POF3 in three samples, which most probably come from the decomposition of LiPF6. Fig. 5f and Fig. S17 show 13C NMR spectrum, the spectrum of aged VEC-15 shows additional detectable intensities in the region between 55 and 52 ppm, which can be assigned with a high probability to polymer chains of different lengths and, perhaps some Oligo-vinyl ethylene carbonate formed. This may because VEC is easier to react with the decomposition products of LiPF6, suppress the subsequent reactions between POF3 and EC/DMC, which is consistent with the EDX and XPS results. The electrolyte without VEC, fresh electrolyte with VEC and electrolyte with VEC after few weeks has also been characterized by ATR-FTIR, the obtained spectrums are shown in (Fig. 5g and 5 h), divide into two major spectral region of VEC added electrolyte, 700–2000 cm−1 and 2000–3200 cm−1. A very weak peak at 3094 cm−1 is the unique asymmetric stretch of the vinylene group = CH2 in VEC in spectra of two. Colour changed VEC-15 has strong new features in the C-H stretching region, especially in the region near 2960 and 2860 cm−1, indicates that there is a mixture of aliphatic methylenes (−CH2−) and methyl (−CH3) groups in the colored electrolyte. The features at 3000 and 2930 cm−1, common to all spectra in Fig. 5h, corresponding to the methylenes (−CH2−) asymmetric and symmetric modes in a saturated heteroatom cyclic ring, e.g., in EC, VEC. It is noted that the aliphatic methyl (−CH3) intensity increase in VEC added electrolyte, suggesting the VEC additive reacted with or decomposed in the electrolyte and more −CH3 groups were produced. The strong and broad carbonyl peak at about 1760 cm−1 could be attributed to lactone of EC and VEC in spectrum of VEC added electrolyte, which split into two peaks and a new peak appears at 1726 cm−1, and also the peaks at 910 cm−1 split to two peaks after few weeks, indicate VEC decomposed, and the peaks have shift because of the effect of carbon double bond. The intensity of peaks at 1410–1370 and 1480 cm−1 decrease, which attribute to methenyl (−CH-) and saturated methylene, other peaks at 1456 cm−1 becomes clearly means cycloalkane exists in the electrolyte. According to the analysis of FTIR, there is a possible that after few weeks, some long-chain polymers or cycloalkane is produced through the polymerization of VEC decomposed products, which is consist with the NMR result.

The LiPF6 in organic solvents decomposed to form strong Lewis acids of PF5 and POF3 when trace water existed, which was used as a common cationic polymerization initiator [52,53], acts as catalysts, inducing the ring-opening reaction [54,55], causing EC decomposition and finally the cell degradation. When VEC used as an electrolyte additive, with the increased activity by the double bond, VEC is easy to catalysts by Lewis acids, induces the free radical reaction and polymerization (Fig. 6 a and b), which in turn prohibit the decomposition of EC and DMC. The reductive decomposition of VEC has been calculated with B3LYP/6-311G (d, p) methods. The initial possible products were studied by Chen’s group [56], formation of the radical anion A1 (LiO2CHOCH2CH(CH = CH2)) results in much more energy releasing, thus, in this simulation, we start from A1, butadiene as the monomer to repeated addition reaction with A1, which was detect in the DEMS characterization. The possible termination ways of radical anion A1 are shown in Fig. 6c and Fig. S17. From A1 to A5, the thermodynamically are not very competitive as shown by their Gibbs free energies of reactions, but still show the possibility, especially, once the long chain radical anion formed, it is expected that the probably barrier- free to form polymers and Li2CO3. The potential energy surface and Gibbs free energy surface profiles are shown in Fig. S19. The intermediate state characteristic of A1 to A5, the most stable products among the involved reactions is the P4 and P5, due to the lowest Gibbs free energy, generates a macromolecular. The Gaussian calculations are in good agreement with the FTIR, NMR and XPS results. Based on above analyses, we can believe that VEC as a sacrificing material contribute to the formation of stable SEI, change the composition, relative concentration and distribution of the organic and inorganic compounds of the SEI layer. The different long-chain oligomer or macromolecule and the relative high content of Li2CO3 and LiF perform the key function to stabilize Li metal and optimize the morphology of Li during the cycling process.

The superiorities of self-protected SEI were further validated through full cell testing. Full cells using Li metal anode coupled with LiFePO4 (LFP) or LiNi0.8 Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) cathode were assembled with normal electrolyte or with VEC additive. The cycling stability and the rate capability were studied and compared in Fig. 7 . The cycling stability was tested at 0.1C for the first three cycles, then cycled at 0.5C (1C = 140 mA g−1). The initial charge/discharge capacity is about 150/148.1 mAh g−1, corresponding to a high ICE of 98.7%, in the VEC-based electrolyte, which is higher than that in normal electrolyte (142.4/136.1 mAh g−1, ICE = 95.5%). After 100 cycles at 0.5C, the VEC-15 full cell was very stable and the coulombic efficiency further increased above 99%. On the contrary, the full cell with normal electrolyte shows obviously capacity decay and the coulombic efficiency is only 92.8% after 100 cycles. The rate capabilities of the different full cell were tested at various C rates from 0.1C to 5C and the results shown in Fig. 7d. The rate performance of full cell with VEC additive is much better than the full cell with normal electrolyte. Fig. 7e shows the SEM image of Li foil cycled in the normal electrolyte, in which the Li foil surface was corrosion and porous structure has been observed. On the contrary, for the VEC-based electrolyte, a smooth surface of Li metal was maintained because of the stable SEI layers.

The anode free Cu|NMC811 cell has also been tested to confirm the high stability of SEI film with VEC additives. (Fig. 8 a and b) show the first three charge/discharge curves of these anode free cell at 0.1C with different electrolyte. Obviously, the capacity decayed rapidly in normal electrolyte even just three cycles due to the dead Li formation. The lithium is limited and only comes from the cathode side and electrolyte, depleted fast within 20 cycles in normal electrolyte. On the contrary, the charge/discharge curves overlapped very well in VEC-15 electrolyte with a high initial coulombic efficiency of 92.5%. Based on our knowledge, this is the first time get such high ICE for anode-free cell with NMC811 using carbonate-based electrolyte. The cell polarization is also reduced in VEC added electrolyte in comparison to the cell with normal electrolyte. As shown in Fig. S20, from the 5th, 10th, 20th charge/discharge curves, the lithium deposition potential increased dramatically in normal electrolyte which is certificated by the shoulder of the charge profiles at the beginning, because of the accumulated dead lithium significant increase the Li ion diffusion resistant. However, the shape of the charge/discharge curves still maintained very well in VEC-15 based electrolyte, and after 20 cycles the capacity retention is 62.7% (based on the first cycle at 0.5C). Even after 50 cycles, there are still active lithium exist, and the average coulombic efficiency is 97.3%. In order to analysis the difference of the cycling performance, we disassembled the anode-free cells until it failure to characterize the morphology of the lithium deposited on the Cu foil. As shown in Fig. 8e and 8f, a lot of dendritic like dead lithium were observed on the Cu foil which is obtained in normal electrolyte, while, in the VEC-15 based electrolyte, the lithium deposited with large particle size around 5–10 µm and still stick on the Cu foil. Moreover, the anode-free cell cycled in a wide voltage range of 3–4.4 V and various charge/discharge rate were also tested and compared as shown in Fig. S21. When the anode-free cell charged at 0.1C and discharge at 1/3C, a higher capacity retention ratio of 69.2% (based on 1st cycle) after 20 cycles has been obtained, however the average coulombic efficiency decreased to 95.9% after 50 cycles. The higher capacity retention but lower average coulombic efficiency could attribute to several reasons. Lithium deposited under a lower current rate at 0.1C (corresponding to charge process of the anode-free cell), decreasing the nucleation potential and benefit for uniform lithium deposition which can increase the reversibility of the limited lithium. However, the wider range voltage during charge/discharge can cause electrolyte decomposition and parasitic reaction, thus decreasing the average coulombic efficiency. The results obtained in this anode-free cell is comparable or even better than that achieved in high concentrated electrolyte or bisalts electrolyte (Table S1). Further improve the anode-free cell performance can be conducted by applied pressure and increase the temperature during cycling, which can improve the lithium metal growth morphology [57,58]. The higher capacity with better stability observed for the full cell with VEC-15 electrolyte can be attribute to the high stability of lithium metal anode. The greatly improved cycling performances in different full cells demonstrate the high stability of lithium metal enabled by self-protected solid-electrolyte-interphase.

In summary, VEC additive effects on the stable and uniform deposition of Li metals were comprehensive studied. The VEC additive is easier to react with LiPF6 and its decomposed products, which further induced ring open reaction and free radical polymerization of VEC, as a result, the side reaction between lithium and EC/DMC was prohibited, as confirmed by XPS, NMR and FTIR. A long chain and cycloparaffin polymer film spontaneously form self-protected SEI layer, which prevents the direct contact and parasitic reactions of the electrolyte with Li, reduce the gas evolution and regulate the lithium deposition behavior to dendrites-free structure during Li plating/stripping processes. Thus, a stabilized Li+ mass/charge transfer through the Li/electrolyte interface, which brings greatly improved Li plating/stripping ability. The performance of Li||LFP and Cu|NMC811 cells with VEC additive demonstrate significantly improved cycle performance compared with the cell using normal electrolyte. This study demonstrated that the self-protected SEI film can greatly improve the stability of Li mental anode in carbonate-based electrolyte and shows practical application prospect of Li mental anode for high-energy batteries.
